discussion.content: Horribly worded question, would be so easy to put "his or her" instead of "an"
The verbiage here is terrible, "checks an IP address..." is vague. If it said, "A user checks his or her IP address on an external website" it would make much better sense.

questions.question_text: A user checks an IP address using an external website. The address is different than the one the user sees when opening a command prompt and typing in ipconfig/all. The user does not understand why the two tools show different IP addresses. This is BEST explained by the interworking of:

discussion.content:
Broadband technologies divide the bandwidth available on a
medium (for example, copper or fibre-optic cabling) into different channels.

comments.content: I'm pretty sure "Broadband" is more layman than ISDN

questions.question_text: Which of the following communication media can carry many voice, data, and video channels simultaneously over multiple frequencies?

choices.C: Add a second UPS into the rack
choices.A: Add a redundant power supply to the switch
choices.B: Implement stacking on the switches in the rack
choices.D: Install a power converter for the switch

comments.content: Agreed with K123, that made C is a better answer.

Agree, letter A is right. A UPS is just a temporary or back up energy source. What if the repair or maintenance of the other UPS that you choose will take long? The UPS won't sustain the longer hours. A redundant power supply will do. Just remember UPS is temporary, and if a problem states about efficiency specially in times of trouble and repair then you would choose a back up power that is not temporary.
What is going to connect to the extra UPS if there is no extra power supply??
Incorrect, 2nd power supply wasn't plugged into the UPS, it's plugged into the switch to keep the switch online when the UPS is being modified.

A redundant power supply is when a single piece of networking equipment operates using two or more physical power supplies. Each of the power supplies will have the capacity to run the device on its own. This makes sure that the device could operate normally even if one power supply fails. A is the correct answer.

I also thought that at first, unless the redundant power supply is plugged into the wall and not the ups and only used when changing out or servicing the UPS. The only way another UPS would work is if there is another power supply, which makes A still correct. If you plugged one UPS into the other, you would still need to shut down the whole system to service the UPS plugged directly into the server.

discussion.content: Two power supplies plugged into one UPS would still take down the switch if the UPS was down, right? I think an additional UPS and an additional power supply would be a better answer.

The key is identifying the problem to focus on. A failed UPS and not having redundant UPS aren't good things. But the main issue in this question isn't UPS redundancy: it's switch availability. The switch having to be taking offline is the problem. If you add a 2nd power supply to the switch, you can swap a connected UPS without taking the switch offline (and you have the option to have a 2nd UPS for even more power redundancy if you have a second power supply in the switch). "A" is correct and addresses the main issue.

questions.question_text: To replace a defective UPS, the network administrator must take the switch offline. The administrator wants to be able to perform maintenance UPS in the future without affecting the availability of the attached switch. Which of the following would BEST allow this to happen?

choices.C: The existing wireless network should be configured to allow guest access
choices.D: An additional wireless network should be configured to allow guest access
choices.B: Guests should log into the current wireless network using credentials obtained upon entering the facility
choices.A: Guests should log into a separate wireless network using a captive portal

questions.question_text:
A network engineer is configuring wireless access for guests at an organization. Access to other areas in the organization should not be accessible to guests.
Which of the following represents the MOST secure method to configure guest access to the wireless network?

discussion.content: A captive portal is a Web page that the user of a public-access network is obliged to view and interact with before access is granted.

comments.content: Because it creates a talking point where everyone can chip in and learn from other people knowledge. :)
How can you ask that when you have Google?
Because the other answers are dumb.
for ex: Wifi in hotel, airports or MC Donalds... most of them would have captive portal
that site is said tobe a captive portal
ever being to the malls and need wifi to browse about the product. They network usually directs you to a "temporary" site where you need to sign up and log in in order to usethe free wifi

discussion.content: If you've ever used a guest network at a coffee shop, gym, or hotel... the captive portal is the window that opens and displays a long user agreement that you say "ok" to without reading.

I've heard of a captive portal, but also I remember seeing the Wi-Fi password on a sheet of paper in a plastic stand on the check in desk at doctor's offices, so I don't understand how it can only be "A."

comments.content: They are asking which one represents the MOST secure method. Given the parameters of the scenario, if you gave someone the password to the business network, they would essentially have access to all assets on that network (work stations, servers, printers, etc.). A guest probably doesn't need access to that, you are just giving them Wi-Fi/Internet access as a courtesy.

questions.question_text: A forensic first responder arrives at the scene where an employee is suspected to have committed a computer-based crime. Which of the following should the first responder do FIRST?

discussion.content:
From Mike Meyer's book:

In general, when you are in a situation where you are the first
responder, you need to

• Secure the area
• Document the scene
• Collect evidence
• Interface with authorities

comments.content: I believe that this topic is covered in the A+, which is considered fair game for the Network+ since Comptia assumes you have the knowledge.

discussion.content: I agree with the answer and even chose that answer. However, this isn't covered in ANY network+ study material or compTIA's criteria for the exam. So why is it even on here?
Todd Lammle touches a bit of it in his Network+ Study Guide
